intro: Aporosella chacoensis, commonly known as the Chacoan aporosella, is a flowering plant native to the Chaco region of South America. It belongs to the family Malvaceae, which includes cotton and hibiscus, and is characterized by its soft, hairy stems and broad leaves. The plant produces small, yellow flowers that are typically clustered in inflorescences. It thrives in dry, sandy soils and is adapted to the semi-arid climate of its native habitat. Due to its limited distribution, it is considered a rare and potentially endangered species.
